content.description: Not the most classic route on the Main Wall, but worth doing. Boulder past the first bolt, then make some big moves on good holds to a stance at the base of the steep. Bust out a boulder-y lip turn and follow improving holds to the chains.* Worth noting that although the chains are bolted in the drip line, the anchor-clipping holds stay dry, making this one viable in the seepy season.
content.location: 10ft to the right of Willy vs. Dave (11b/12a). Look for a prominent right-facing corner above the first bolt.

content.description: Start on slopers to gain a juggy roof. Pull through a few crimps and climb a left facing corner to the anchors.
content.location: The left of two routes that start up on the hill left of the Main Wall

content.description: Begin on the right side of the gully. Meander up the featured slab to cold shut anchors.
content.protection: light rack, nothing bigger than a .5 Camalot. Cold shuts at the top.
content.location: Tea & Crumpets wall. From the approach trail, walk left (less than 100 yards) until you come to a shallow gully. This route starts on the right side of the gully.

content.description: Crimpy start friendly trees. Rest ledge around corner at third bolt. Traverse then up to handle before longer runout to flat rock. Stand for shuts.
content.location: Continue on Cumberland Trail past Transformers rock, run up left to first corner route. 5-10 minutes from Tea and Crumpets wall.

content.description: Tricky slab with an uneven landing should you blow the first bolt. Continue with balance moves to easier edges near the end.
content.location: Hemlock Wall, up the hill and left of a large roof with a couple of sport routes. Right of Ermahgerd.

content.description: Climb a seam corner to the first roof and continue out another long, flat roof on flakes to a face. Work up several face moves separated by jugs to the final bolt. Find the hidden clipping holds for the anchor or just lock-off some slopers and go for the clip. Decent climbing on this section of good rock
content.location: From the approach trail, this is on the right side of the largest section of overhanging rock.

content.description: Start on face, do a long reach to get into the roof.  Once on the roof do some unique and technical climbing to lip. Once at the lip make the decision to try the bat hang for a rest or make the push for the top.

Start left of Whipping Post on the dusty ledge. *beware the poison ivy* Work up the blocky, moist, and dirty goodness through the second bolt to gain a nice jug and contemplate how to clip the third bolt. Leaving the jug and standing up into a couple pinches begins the crux.(aim right) Sort out the long moves through the next bolt or two to a porpoise head jug rest. From here move left with liebacks and underclings to a fantastic sequence that puts you at the base of the arete. Enjoy the spectacular climbing up the arete as you cruise to the chains!
Boulder problem through the shallow crack then fun moves to top where another crux protects the anchors.
content.location: 2nd route from right on shadow wall

content.description:
Fantastic route with an array of fun movement and even some glamorous kneebar action if that's your thing. 

  Cruise through some 5.11 terrain initially to reach the base of the roof/dihedral crack. Pump your way up the groove and make a big huck to a flat ledge. Mantel the ledge and wind back the pump clock for the finale. 

  From the ledge, grab some smaller holds in a sequential manner to gain access to the finishing jugs.
content.location: Starts to the right of "Strutter"

content.description:
A distinctive roof with flakes(crux) leads to a no hands rest on a pillar.  Steep, juggy 5.11+ to the top. 

  Most people stick clip the first two bolts
content.protection: Bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Right of Leakage.

content.description: Great moves the whole way. Sustained but positive climbing leads you up through a series of small overhangs to a crux on rounded crimps up high.
content.protection: bolts, bolts with quicklinks on the ledge below the big roof up top
content.location: Walk climber's left out of the Stallion Cave and up the hill. The trail will squeeze past a big boulder and then start back downhill again. As you head down the hill there are two 5.11 climbs right next to each other. This is the left one.

content.description:
Another 12+ at Deep Creek?!?!  Yep. 

  This one differs a bit from the others in that the 12d is all in the first half of the route.  Start out by climbing up into a corner and gaining a flat horizontal, traversing back out above the first bolt.  Do a funky move to gain the next horizontal at the 2nd and traverse out left towards the lip of the roof.  Clip a bolt out the roof and execute the crux either using to edges under the roof making a large deadpoint to a very sloping rail or moving a bit left and doing harder but higher percentage moves.  The crux isn't over yet...make some sequential moves through a crack feature moving up and right towards an obvious ledge.  Rest, take your hands off, and then climb a 12- from here to the top.  Great route only marred by the no hands after the hard climbing.  Amazing rock.
content.location: Located in between Nugs and Feast of Fools. Has cleaning quick link at the 3rd bolt in the roof.

content.description:
Awesome!  Sustained climbing that leads to a high crux, then a red point "pumped-out-of-yer-mind" crux on the still sustained climbing above. 

  Boulder past a small, low roof, rest, then continue up making long moves to descent holds.  A brief crux near the 7th(?) bolt will reward you with inflamed forearms and no rest until the anchors.
content.protection: 9 bolts and a can of spinach
content.location: Main wall, between the Deep Show and Knee Deep.  Identified by a hole-ish feature at the 2nd bolt

climbs.name: Mo'cheeba
climbs.fa: Bolted by Anthony Meeks, FA by Cody Averbeck

content.description: Figure out the cryptic sequences to get you through the first couple of bolts, then keep it together through the less difficult remainder to get your points. You'll know you're doing the bottom wrong because it'll feel v7 instead of v4. The top actually climbs really well on good stone, and this one will probably be dry when the others are wet.
content.location: Right of the mole. Look for obvious left handed side pull sloper below the first bolt.

content.description: Leakage is one amazing haul. Without any of the no hands rest that plague the other routes on the wall, Leakage requires some real recovery. The shakeouts are there but each one yields a little less, and the climbing doesn't let up until the top.
content.location: Leakage is located on the left side of the Main Wall and is identified by a slightly lower than normal first bolt and a crack feature up high.

content.description: Ga'Jammit's less aesthetic neighbor, Knee Deep is nevertheless wild for the grade. Big sloping jugs give way to flat plates and edges as the pump factor multiplies.
content.location: Directly to the left of Ga'Jammit.

content.description: Must have walked by this thing a thousand times and I've never seen it. Dope route, fun boulder down low to a no hands stance: take it, cause you're gonna need it. Find your beta for 'the hole' and then classic deep creek jug hauling awaits you. Don't punt from the chains.
content.location: Starts directly right of Gah'jamit, right where the approach trail spits you out.

content.description: The first route you will see at Deep Creek. After slithering up the funky crack feature, incredible steep climbing leads through an explosive crux at a beach ball sized hole. Manage the pump or be thwarted by a sneaky sequence at the chains.
content.location: The obvious steep route where the trail meets the rock.

content.description: New route in between "Nuggz" and "Mongo's Fury" bolted by Cody Averbeck in Spring of 2021. Quest out dank roof flakes to a freakish boosh move at the lip. Mantle up, take a breather, then pump out easier climbing to anchors below the dripline.
content.location: In between "Nuggz" and "Mongo's Fury".

content.description: Climb typical deep creek sloping holds trending up and left for the first 3/4 of the route to where the rock changes to reddish brown and the moves get increasingly harder with the crux being from the last bolt to the chains.  Great route with great rock and none of the no hands rests that plague a large portion of the other routes on this wall.
content.protection: Bolts to a double bolt anchor.
content.location: To the left of the Ear and right of Feast of Fools.  Starts the same as the Ear and breaks left...make sure to not stick clip the first bolt on the Ear, but the further left bolt at the same height.

content.description: Climb the first six bolts of Leakage. Split right and plow through some crimps followed by classic deep creek style long pulls on good holds. Gear up below the final bolt and slam dunk the all points off dyno which, if you catch it, earns you a final run out to the chains. This is a direct finish to Leakage, and is honestly surprising it took so long to get the bolts in. Mad dope rock climbing.
content.location: Shares start and first six bolts with Leakage.

content.description:
Would get another star if it weren't for all the sand in the horizontals. Still a very fun route and worth doing. 

  Clamber up to a nice stance before the first roof. Hustle over this and continue to weave your way up through dramatic overhangs until things finally start to ease off below the last big roof. Unfortunately the bolts end here. (I'm guessing because the last big roof is often wet?) Traverse right along the ledge to bolted anchors shared with the neighboring routes.
content.protection: 5 bolts, then a hard right along the ledge to anchors
content.location: Walk climber's left out of the Stallion Cave and up the hill. The trail will squeeze past a big boulder and then start back downhill again. Look for Flat and Sassy as you're headed down the hill.

content.description: Wrestle your way past three dimensional climbing at the first bolt and chase a series of long moves on good holds, then watch out for choss and sand as you climb into a no hands rest. Recover from your recent bout, and get ready for a tricky boulder problem which gives the route it's grade. Finish is airy on thin holds and slabby feet above the final bolt. This one dries out faster than the few routes to its right, so it's a good candidate for when The Ear, Deep Show, and Freak Magnet are wet.
content.location: To the left of Freak Magnet.

content.description: The bolted line just right of Freak Magnet. Pull through jugs and crimps to a standing no hands rest, then tackle the overhanging face above.
content.location: Just right of Freak Magnet

content.description: The Deep Show might just break a few hearts. After a nice rest at the third bolt, the climbing is relentless and culminates with all-out, technical fight to the chains.
content.location: Main Wall. Between The Mole and The Ear at a low juggy roof.

content.description: FUN STEEP ROUTE, SHOULDER MOVE OFF SLOPER TO ANOTHER SLOPER OUT RIGHT. EASIER CLIMBING TAKES YOU TO A BIG MOVE GUARDING THE ANCHORS
content.location: FURTHEST ROUTE LEFT ON FIRST AND LAST WALL BEFORE THE CREEK AND BEFORE THE HEMLOCK WALL ON LOGGING WALL

content.description: Climb some good old Deep Creek Steep to a bouldery throw and finish on an excellent patina crimp face.
content.location: On the hanging block on the far right side of Main Wall. Second route from the left in this area.

content.description: Climb deep incut jugs reminiscent of the RRG to the first bolt. Continue up with big moves between slopers and jugs to a crux on small holds at the last bolt.
content.location: About 100' past the buttress with Proof of Life towards the Woodshed wall. The left face of a corner to the right of a big roof.

content.description: Main Wall hosts the highest concentration of classic routes at Deep Creek, most of them in the 5.12 range. Unfortunately, many of these routes seep at the top, especially during Winter and Spring seasons. However, you can count on the section of cliff from Gunlinger (13-) to Leakage (12a) to almost always be dry. Nuggs and Mondo's Fury are usually dry too, however I don't have personal experience with those routes, so I'm not quite as positive. Most routes here are thuggy, steep, and powerful, with mostly good holds on perfect sandstone.
